entry.title: TM Scheduling of Sales / Purchasing / Delivery Documents with BPS Integration
entry.content:
Dear friends of TM,

With S/4HANA 2023 FPS01, we released the long-awaited TM based Sales Order Scheduling for embedded TM in a first version for the determination of durations for transport-relevant activities. Following that, we already planned a more complex but also more accurate determination of dates and times for transport-relevant activities, which we published with S/4HANA 2023 FPS02.

But at this time, we couldn‚Äôt imagine that this was just the beginning of a journey. And you, the customers, the partners and also many colleagues made this happen with your valuable feedback which motivated us to push this topic further.

As of now, we have enabled the TM based scheduling for five (!) business documents, enhanced the functionality and also spent some BAdIs to enable customers to make modification-free enhancements.

It‚Äôs surely time to provide an overview of the current functionality!

Overview

The following is the general architecture for our TM scheduling:

 

  1. The requested delivery date from the business document is the input for the Business Process Scheduling (BPS), where the calculation of the relevant dates is managed.
  2. Based on the requested delivery date, Transportation Management (TM) can calculate durations or dates/times for the activities loading, transport and unloading by backward scheduling, ending up in a requested picking date. From that, BPS calculates a requested material availability date as input for Available-to-Promise (ATP).
  3. ATP confirms a material availability date of the product from which BPS calculates the respective confirmed picking date.
  4. If this confirmed picking date differs from the requested picking date, TM calculates the confirmed delivery date with forward scheduling. Otherwise, the requested delivery date becomes the confirmed delivery date.

When a business document is integrated with BPS, basically two options are possible:

  • BPS Determination: Durations of defined activities are retrieved. When TM is the source for this retrieval, this can be done with the default route, with straight line distances and durations and with the functionality of the network path determination.
  • BPS Delegation: Dates and times of defined activities are retrieved. Regarding TM, the same means as for the BPS Determination are possible and additionally schedule departures can be considered.
Business Documents

With that, the following business documents are enabled to be integrated with BPS and TM as described before:

Customer Enhancements

As already mentioned, we thankfully received a tremendous amount of feedback. One thing that showed up very early was the fact that customers need more flexibility.

Therefore, we invested in the following BadIs:

During creation of the business document (in the respective transaction, before saving), the Scheduling Handler in TM receives the scheduling request from BPS and compiles it for TRS. This is a new API within TM, designed for the TM scheduling functionality, using existing functions of transportation planning. And when TRS has derived durations or dates/times, those are sent back to BPS. The goal is, to have as much similarities to the transportation planning after logistics integration (means when the business document is finally created and persisted) as possible.

In the Scheduling Handler, BAdI /SCMTMS/BADI_LI_TRS_BTD_CHG has been introduced with a note and offers the following two enhancement options:

  • At the beginning of the Scheduling Handler, the input data from the business document can be adjusted. This method has the same interface as BAdI /SCMTMS/BADI_LI_BTD_CHG where business document data at the beginning of logistics integration can be adjusted. This enables customers to use a similar enhancement logic for logistics integration and TM scheduling.
  • Before calling TRS, the respective input data can also be adjusted. 
Further Information

We have collected some of the frequently asked questions in this note.

There's also a note for the support of scheduling agreements and another note for the support of outbound deliveries.

Please, also follow those links in the help portal:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/94b155b3c1524164add6b448dc3186dc.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/69fc86c287fe44ff8033efe4e66743d7.html

Best regards,

Michael

entry.title: AMS instance-based (row-level) filtering not applied in CAP using dynamic user attributes
entry.content:
Issue: AMS instance-based filtering not working as expected in CAP
We are using AMS to implement row-level (instance-based) filtering in a CAP service. Below is a minimal reproducible example.

Schema
 
SCHEMA {
Supplier: String,
$user: {
supplierid: String
}
}
 
AMS Policy

POLICY ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER { GRANT read ON FPOReview WHERE Supplier = $user.supplierid; }

Service & Entity

service FPOService @(path: '/fpo-service')
{ entity FPOReview as projection on my.FPOReview { Supplier, * };
annotate FPOReview with @AMS.attributes: { Supplier: (Supplier) };
}
 
User Token (excerpt)
 
{ "supplierid": "17008974" }

Observed Behavior
When the user is assigned to policy ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER in IAS, the service returns all rows, instead of filtering records where Supplier = 17008974.
When we add @requires: ['ZSP_POLICY_MANAGER'] on the service or entity, the request starts failing with 403 Forbidden.

Questions
1. Is AMS expected to automatically apply row-level filtering based on @AMS.attributes and the policy condition (Supplier = $user.supplierid)?

2. Should assigning the policy alone be sufficient to filter records, or is @requires mandatory‚Äîand if so, why does it result in 403 Forbidden

Our requirement is to restrict data so that users only see records for suppliers assigned to them. While we can implement this manually in JavaScript handlers, we want to understand how AMS can be utilised for this use case, especially around dynamic attributes.

We are using a custom schema defined in IAS to obtain the supplier ID list. To simplify the initial testing and verify that dynamic attributes are working correctly, we have temporarily added a simple string attribute supplierid to the custom schema. We are able to successfully retrieve this value in our CAP application, but policies are not working.

entry.title: Re: Plants abroad active, MWST Tax is not determined in B...
entry.content:
When plants abroad are activated, SAP considers the billing plant‚Äôs country as the departure country. Example Material shipped from Germany, billed by Denmark plant. Departure = Denmark, Destination = Denmark ‚Üí MWST 20% should apply. If departure is Germany and destination is Germany, MWST % should apply according to German tax rules.
Since in your case, you mentioned some user exit is in place, we cannot assist you for this issue. Take the help of your ABAP team to find out the root cause.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Test Automation Tool in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition CE2602
entry.content:
Introduction 

As we continue to innovate and enhance the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool (TAT), the CE2602 release brings powerful new capabilities designed to make post-upgrade testing smarter, faster, and more efficient. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through the latest features delivered with CE2602, including advanced comparison options in the Post Upgrade Test (PUT) App, enhanced TDC AutoBind integration, and a new capability in i-TS for Smart Execution. These improvements aim to simplify test management, expand coverage, and reduce manual effort‚Äîhelping you achieve greater accuracy and productivity in your testing workflows.

Full Scope Comparison (PUT application)

The Full Scope Comparison feature provides a holistic view of two PUT executions (Standard & Custom) across different releases or runs.

  • Comprehensive Analysis: Compare two complete PUT executions for detailed insights.
  • Side-by-Side Summary: View execution details, triggers, and timestamps for quick reference.
  • Impact Identification: Rapidly detect post-upgrade changes across the entire PUT landscape for thorough validation and risk mitigation.

Fig.1 : Execution comparator showcasing the comparison feature of two test runs

Comparison of Custom Automates (PUT application)

This feature enables detailed analysis of custom automated test plans across different PUT runs.

  • Cross-Run Comparison: Analyse custom PUT automated test plans executed in two different runs.
  • Instance-Level Status: Displays detailed status for each test plan, such as:
    • Success
    • Failed
    • Pre-checks Failed
    • Cancelled

Fig.2 : Showcases comparison support for customer test plans

Enhanced AutoBind for Test Data Container Integration

AutoBind logic has been significantly improved to make test setup faster and more accurate.

  • Intelligent Mapping: Maps Test Data Container (TDC) fields to script labels for both Standard & PUT automates.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures precise alignment between test data and scripts.
  • Reduced Manual Effort: Minimises manual intervention during test setup.

Fig. 3 : Showcases enhanced auto bind capability for TDC integration

Scoping Capability (PUT application)

The new Smart Execution feature enhances flexibility by allowing users to include i-TS recommended scope along with custom scope in custom variants.

  • Comprehensive Coverage: Combine i-TS recommended processes with standard and custom-defined processes while executing a custom variant for PUT.
  • Flexible Execution: Provides control to selectively merge scopes for a unified test run.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures critical i-TS recommended scenarios are validated alongside custom flows for reliable post-upgrade assessment.

Fig. 4 : Showcases capability to include i-TS recommended processes while executing a custom variant for PUT

Why It Matters

These updates significantly improve testing efficiency, enhance data accuracy, reduce manual setup effort, and boost overall productivity across all post-upgrade test automation workflows.

SAP Delivered Standard Automates

The total list of SAP delivered automated test scripts are 505 for 2602 release and can be accessed via link ‚Äì Automated Test Scripts Index‚Äù. This includes 26 new scope items which were added this release.

Further detailed change information about the standard automate is available in the ‚ÄúTest Script Release Change Information‚Äù.

Learn More: 

Important Links and Updates

We have created a new Learning Hub course for an overview of the tool. This is a good starting point for anyone who is new to the tool or want to get an overview of the new features we have added over the past couple of years. [Before you can access the link, a one-time registration in the SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required. A detailed step-by-step guidance can be found here]

 As part of our PUT 2.0 Enablement also we have created a set of short videos which cover the most important aspects of the process. The video playlist can be accessed here.

 Links to other important blogs:

  • How to get started with the Test Automation Tool for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Please bookmark the test automation community page to keep up with the latest updates happening in the test automation space.

For more details on the functionality please refer the links below:

  • Post-Upgrade Tests App
  • Intelligent Test Scoper (i-TS) 
  • Manage Upgrade Tests 
  • Manage Your Test Processes
  • Test Your Processes
  • Test Data Container
  • Analyze Automated Test Results
  • Configure Conditional Authentication
  • Also refer FAQs

Questions, feedback, or tips? Comment below or connect with us on SAP Community! Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts.

Follow us on @SAP and #S4HANA, and myself on LinkedIn.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud: Q4 2025 Innovation Highlights
entry.content:
SAP Sales Cloud: Q4 2025 Innovation Highlights

With a robust set of AI-first innovations already delivered throughout 2025, SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs Q4 update continues to expand intelligent capabilities, flexibility, extensibility, and key workflow enhancements to maximize sales productivity. This blog will cover a few key feature highlights that are worth a closer look. For a more in-depth showcase on these capabilities and more, we invite you to register for the SAP Sales Cloud Innovation and Foundation webcast on Wednesday, January 28th. Register today to stay on top of new innovations and enhancements, as well as exciting details on our 2026 solution roadmap.

Additional innovation resources: SAP CX Portfolio    l    SAP Service Cloud and ESM

What‚Äôs New in SAP Sales Cloud

Naturally 2025 was a year of enhancing and embedding agentic AI capabilities within SAP Sales Cloud and the extended lead-to-cash value chain, but we also released a significant number of enhancements around ease of use, specific customer requests, quality-of-life improvements for admins, Joule for B2B sales, and developments designed to further streamline sales processes with deep integration and infused AI. Additionally, the AI agent builder continues to be enhanced so users can easily create and deploy agentic B2B sales use cases in clicks. With so many exciting new features and enhancements we can‚Äôt cover them all here‚Ä¶ so without further ado, here are four highlights from our Q4 2025 SAP Sales Cloud release to dig into.   

AI-enhanced Quote Generation

Opportunities are constantly changing as deals progress, especially in complex deal cycles with detailed configuration or changing requirements. SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs AI-enhanced Quote Generation helps remove guesswork and reduces manual effort by automatically creating draft quotes. The solution‚Äôs quotation AI agent works in the background, reading and analyzing rich data and email content for key information. From the data analysis, Sales Cloud extracts customer intent and intended product line items, automatically creating a draft quote for the appropriate opportunity. Commonly referred to as ‚ÄúAI ‚Äì Email to Quote‚Äù, this feature replaces manual configuration and helps sales organizations shorten response times. Sellers are then free to quickly review, augment if needed, and send the quote without being bogged down in complexity.

SAP Sales Cloud + Microsoft Teams: Chat Experience

Our existing release of SAP Sales Cloud already included deep integration with Microsoft Teams, but our Q4 2025 release greatly expanded this experience with embedded Chat. Now users can Teams Chat directly within SAP Sales Cloud. Peer-to-peer, meeting follow up, or group chats are seamlessly supported so users can start, view, and continue key conversations without leaving Sales Cloud. This enhancement helps users stay connected, faster without losing context or needing to switch between applications. Customer-related communication is tied to the relevant CRM data so users can engage, collaborate, and progress deals quickly.

AI Duplicate Check Enhancement

Legacy CRM systems often have notoriously bad or duplicate data for a variety of reasons, but we are determined to make this issue a thing of the past. SAP Sales Cloud follows clean core development principles and our vision for data quality and orchestration is an extension of this mindset. As we look to the future of B2B sales, AI is and will play a critical role, but AI is only as good as the data it consumes. AI Duplicate Check within Sales Cloud uses embedded intelligence to uncover loose, partial, and soft match duplicates so users can easily unite and clean records to improve quality with little effort. Our Q4 2025 update strengthens these capabilities and has been optimized to help sellers with lead flow. Once a seller has qualified a lead and is ready to move the prospect into an opportunity cycle, AI Duplicate Check reviews CRM data and guides the user to link the lead / converted opportunity to the appropriate account or CRM records. This feature can dramatically simplify lead conversion while improving user experience and data quality.

Subscription Contracts and Renewals

With ongoing market disruption and quickly evolving industry trends, flexible business models and dynamic solution offerings continue to rise in popularity. In this regard we have enhanced SAP Sales Cloud‚Äôs ability to better support subscription offerings with high complexity through a deep integration with SAP CPQ. Now users can easily create subscription contracts or solution renewals for complex offerings from an opportunity with just a few clicks. The streamlined integration unites Sales Cloud, CPQ, and SAP Cloud ERP, providing a consistent subscription flow from opportunity, to quote, to order, and contract. Once fulfilled account and opportunity records automatically synchronize, providing a clear and consistent source of truth.

Ready for more?

We‚Äôre very excited to showcase these and more highlights on the SAP Sales Cloud Innovation and Foundation webcast on Wednesday, January 28th. In addition to a deeper dive and solution demonstration of these features, we will also share upcoming roadmap items and answer questions in real-time. To dive deeper into specific use cases or for a personalize showcase drop us a note on SAP.com.

entry.title: üá¶üá∫ Gen AI Hub & Joule Studio : Create Skills and AI Agents to Extend Joule (Brisbane, Australia)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event comprised of 2 parts.

1. Getting Started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core with Python. You do not need any background in the topic, but you should have a lot of curiosity! Here you will learn how to use the Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). This approach improves the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduces hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core, and how to query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Additionally, you will gain insights into key generative AI concepts and learn how to enhance RAG responses.

2. Introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Friday, February 13, 2026 from 09:00 - 15:30 local time in Brisbane, Australia AEST (Australian Eastern Standard Time). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: Gold Tower, Level 27/10 Eagle St, Brisbane City QLD 4000, Australia

  • The event is kindly being hosted by UpperGround by Hudson
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocates @Shilpa_Shankar and @Rekha_DR 

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 35 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.

entry.title: Don't Let Your Integration Take a Coffee Break: Client Certificate Changes In 2026!
entry.content:
Introduction

If integrations were people, you‚Äôd dread them slipping out for coffee breaks just when you need them most. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Integrated Business Planning (IBP), and SAP Marketing Cloud (SMC) are all about to experience an important update to how client certificates are issued. This change, prompted by evolving industry standards, involves a change of the Certificate Authority (CA) for the Default Client certificate. It‚Äôs important to note that this CA change has the potential to cause one of those dreaded coffee breaks‚Äîdisruptions in connectivity‚Äîif not handled properly.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening, who should pay attention, and how to keep your setup on track.

Who Is Affected?

If you use the Client Default certificate for outbound authentication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, or SMC, this change applies to you. Anyone relying on these certificates for outbound integrations should pay attention, as missing the update could lead to disruptions in communication.

This only applies to customer managed integration scenarios. SAP managed ones will be taken care of by SAP, of course.

What Is Changing?

Currently, the Default Client certificates for outbound communication are issued by DigiCert. In February 2026, SAP Cloud Root CA becomes the new certificate authority for newly issued client certificates. You‚Äôll also notice updates to certificate subject names, including additional organizational fields. These changes will be present in all new client certificates issued during routine rotation.

To help visualize the upcoming changes, here‚Äôs a quick comparison of the old and new default client certificates:

Certificate Attribute

Old (Before Rotation)

New (After Rotation)

Subject

CN=<your tenant hostname>

CN=<your tenant hostname>
OU=<some UID>

Issuer

DigiCert Global G2

SAP Cloud Root CA

Extended Key Usage

Client Authentication,
Server Authentication

Client Authentication

The new OU value is specific to the product (S/4/IBP/ SMC) and will remain the same during future certificate rotations.

Timeline and Notification: When and How Will You be Informed?

New systems will receive client certificates signed by SAP Cloud Root CA starting late March 2026. Existing systems will begin renewal with a staging certificate from late February 2026, fully transitioning during their next scheduled key rotation. In case you wonder: the fact that these dates are close to the 2602 release is a pure coincidence. System upgrades and certificate changes are separate processes.
The rotation schedule and rotation process do not change. There will be no additional certificate rotation.

Example: if your current Client Default certificate is valid until April 2026, the CA change will happen in April for you. If your certificate expires in November, you‚Äôll keep your DigiCert certificate until November and then switch to SAP Cloud Root CA.

The usual notification email about certificate rotation will include additional details about the change in Certificate Authority. Please review it carefully to ensure you understand the updates and can take the right actions in response. The process for certificate rotation is described on this help page.

Potential Issues and Required Action

For clarity, we'll refer to the system, tenant, service, or device that receives and validates connections from your SAP cloud tenant (S/4 cloud, IBP, SMC) as the target environment. Such target environments could be anything from BTP apps, SAP solutions like SAP Ariba or SAP SuccessFactors, third-party products running in the cloud or on-premises, or even custom-built applications.

How Things Might Break

Misalignment of configurations in your SAP cloud tenant and the target environment can lead to two categories of issues:

  • CA Trust Failures: If your target environment does not trust the SAP Cloud Root CA, it will reject the new certificate. In these cases, the mutual TLS (mTLS) handshake fails, and communication is blocked at the TLS layer. No HTTP error code is returned.
  • User / System / Identity Mapping Errors: in the target environment, the certificate metadata (subject, issuer) is mapped to the identity of a user or process. Consequently, if the mapping is not changed to use the new subject and issuer, authorization errors (such as HTTP 403 or 401) will happen. Depending on the implementation of the target environment, TLS errors could also occur.

Technical Aside: Certificate Pinning vs CA Trust

For certificate-based authentication, most target environments will rely on CA trust, where the target environment validates the certificate‚Äôs chain up to a trusted root CA. With the switch to SAP Cloud Root CA, you must add this CA to the trust store in the target environment and check your user mapping logic.

For environments using certificate pinning, simply upload the new certificate when the rotation occurs. In this case, the certificate is identified by the fingerprint of the certificate‚Äôs key rather than the metadata of the certificate (i.e. subject and issuer). Target environments using certificate pinning must be updated every time the certificate rotates ‚Äì the CA change does not make a difference here.

Required Actions for Customers

To maintain uninterrupted integrations, customers using the Client Default certificate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, and SMC should:

  1. Update CA Trust: Make sure the SAP Cloud Root CA is trusted by your target environment. You can download the root certificate from the SAP Trust Center.
  2. Adjust User/System/Identity Mapping: Update your mapping logic to recognize the new certificate subject and issuer, ensuring the target environment properly identifies and authorizes the incoming connection.

More information on the topic is available in SAP note 3677763 as well as the relevant help pages:

  • How to Handle Default Client Certificate Renewal
  • Set Up Certificate-to-User Mapping (SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Marketing Cloud)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for Integration Flow Processing (SAP Integration Suite)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for API Clients (SAP Integration Suite)

Conclusion

While this certificate update might seem like an invitation for your integrations to sneak away for a coffee break, staying alert and updating your trust stores and mappings in your target environment will keep everything running without interruption. Pay attention to notification emails‚Äîso your integrations never miss a beat (or a sip).

entry.title: Hierarchy with Directory in SAP Datasphere ‚Äì Description vs. ID shown inconsistently across folders
entry.content:
Hello SAP Datasphere Community,

I am currently facing an issue with hierarchies created in SAP Datasphere, and I would like to understand whether this is a known behavior or a modeling issue on my side.

I created a product hierarchy with directory using a SQL View. The hierarchy is based on a remote table and exposed into Datasphere via a SQL View. The implementation follows exactly the approach described in the official SAP Community blog post ‚ÄúModeling a basic hierarchy with directory in SAP Datasphere‚Äù. Overall, the setup works as expected: the hierarchy is created correctly, all levels are visible, and it can be used in an Analytic Model. Descriptions are maintained and initially displayed correctly.

However, I am experiencing a problem when reusing the same hierarchy with directory in a different folder. In this case, the hierarchy is still visible and structurally correct in the Analytic Model, but when switching the display setting from ID to Description, the system continues to show the ID instead of the description. This happens even though the descriptions are clearly maintained and work correctly when the hierarchy is used in its original folder.

What makes this behavior particularly confusing is that my modeling approach is always identical, yet the outcome differs. When the hierarchy is used directly on top of the SQL View without persistence, the descriptions are displayed correctly. As soon as the SQL View is persisted, the hierarchy still works structurally, but only IDs are shown and the descriptions are no longer respected in the Analytic Model. The same inconsistency can also be observed when reusing the identical hierarchy definition in a different folder. In some cases, descriptions are displayed correctly, while in others only IDs appear. This inconsistent behavior makes it difficult to identify a clear root cause, as the same hierarchy definition behaves differently depending on persistence and folder context.

Hierarchies coming from BW are currently not an option. The issue occurs repeatedly across multiple hierarchies, not just a single one.

Has anyone experienced similar behavior with hierarchies and directories in SAP Datasphere? Are there known limitations or dependencies when reusing hierarchies across folders or when persisting SQL Views? Could this be related to metadata handling, caching, folder context, or semantic usage in Analytic Models? Any hints, explanations, or best practices to ensure that descriptions are consistently displayed instead of IDs would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Integrating SAP Customer Data Cloud with SAP Emarsys for personalized, compliant marketing
entry.content:
Connecting SAP Emarsys  with SAP Customer Data Cloud brings together two powerful capabilities: personalized, omnichannel marketing and privacy-first customer identity management. The integration creates a single, reliable view of each customer, combining identity, consent and profile data from the Customer Data Cloud with Emarsys‚Äô campaign orchestration and real-time engagement engine

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Why it matters (functionally)

  • Unified profiles: Customers‚Äô identity and preference data from the Customer Data Cloud flow into Emarsys so marketing teams work from consistent, up-to-date profiles.
  • Better segmentation and personalization: Rich attributes and consent signals enable more relevant audience segments and tailored messaging across channels.
  • Privacy and compliance by design: Consent and preference status managed in the Customer Data Cloud are honored in Emarsys campaigns, helping you meet privacy requirements while reducing manual checks.
  • Faster activation: Whether via real-time updates or scheduled syncs, customer changes are reflected quickly so campaigns stay aligned to current behavior and permissions.
  • Reduced data silos and simpler operations: Centralized identity management decreases duplication and cleanup work, freeing teams to focus on strategy and performance.

Practical steps (high level)

  • Establish the connector between platforms and authenticate access.
  • Map key attributes (identity, contact info, preferences, consent) from Customer Data Cloud to Emarsys fields.
  • Decide on sync cadence (real-time vs. batch) and test end-to-end flows.
  • Validate consent flows and ensure opt-ins/opt-outs are enforced in campaigns.
  • Monitor and iterate on segments and journeys to maximize engagement.

Outcome
The result is more trusted, personalized customer engagement that scales without sacrificing compliance. If you‚Äôre looking to improve campaign relevance and reduce manual identity work, this integration is a practical next step.

More info

Official product documentation

  • SAP Emarsys integration guide
  • SAP Customer Data Cloud integration guide

Suggested learning.sap.com resources and what to look for:

  • https://learning.sap.com/courses/getting-started-with-sap-emarsys 
  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Cloud Essentials 
  • Implementing Data Inputs and Integrations in SAP Emarsys

entry.title: From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This January
entry.content:
In the age of AI, the skills we build today will define how we work tomorrow. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôve launched a monthly series of blogs that spotlight the latest AI learning assets and upcoming learning opportunities. This blog explores the latest learning and enablement resources on SAP Document AI, as well as the bi-directional integration between Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot. We also dive into some key resources to help you get started building your own Joule agents.

Building on my first blog, where I introduced you to our AI live sessions Beyond Hype (which is all about getting productive with SAP Business AI), I wanted to address some of your most asked questions:

  1. How can I enable SAP Document AI on my mobile device?
    SAP Document AI also supports mobile use cases, ideally for employees working remotely or in the field who need to submit documents while on the go. Within SAP Mobile Start, you can configure Document AI as a target, then take a picture and automatically upload it for processing. Find out here how to integrate and launch SAP Document AI on mobile. If you haven‚Äôt set up SAP Document AI yet, you want to check out the steps here.

    Did you know about the recent feature release: Inbound and outbound channel support, which allows you to connect your e-mail server, as many document-related use cases involve e-mail. For now, only Microsoft Outlook is supported, but this enables you to fetch the e-mail, extract both the e-mail body and attachments, such as Excel files. For e-mail ingestion, you don‚Äôt need BPA integration; you can also use our e-mail ingestion feature without BPA by configuring your e-mail inbox as an inbound channel in our UI. Read more about the Q4/25 Release Highlights here and follow the documentation to register an e-mail app here.

    Stay up to date with SAP Road Map Explorer and learn how you will benefit from SAP Document AI in upcoming releases.

  2. Where can we find instructions for setting up the bi-directional integration between Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot?
    The great thing is that you can get started today with Joule Base and a Microsoft 365 license by downloading the SAP Joule app from the Microsoft Marketplace (M365 Copilot license required when using M365 Copilot skills in Joule web client in your SAP Application). Then follow the SAP Help documentation to set up the connection between Cloud Identity Services on SAP BTP & Microsoft Entra, and consider a few technical pre-requisites:
    1.  Is Joule activated in at least one SAP Business Applications (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors or SAP S/4HANA Cloud), and do you have administrator access to SAP Cloud Identity Services, SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and Microsoft Entra? Yes? Great, read on!
    2.  Next, you need to:
    • Configure Microsoft Entra as your Corporate Identity Provider
    • Enable Joule to Pass Requests to Microsoft Copilot and Teams
    • Joule Formation to be included with MS Copilot Integration in your system landscape

     Watch my colleague @nageshcaparthy  demo the setup process! 

     

  3. May we use Joule within Microsoft 365 Copilot (and vice versa) when handling confidential data?
    Did you know that Joule and Copilot are only exchanging the user prompt and displaying the result in their respective UIs? Through Identity Propagation between Microsoft Entra and Cloud Identity Services on SAP BTP, Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot are aware of a user‚Äôs roles and permissions for a secure integration. Watch the video and see the two Copilots work together in action! 

     

Want to dive deeper into the content? Rewatch the sessions and access the session material via SAP Learning Hub (subscription required):

  • Getting Started with SAP Document AI: Activate, Automate, Act (recording)
  • Two Copilots, One Goal: Smarter Productivity with Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot (recording)

Speaking of automation and productivity, have you heard that Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available? The agent builder enables developers to create Joule agents tailored to their unique business requirements, breaking cross-ecosystem silos and reducing barriers to AI adoption. Read on in Michael Ameling‚Äôs Blog, President of SAP Business Technology Platform, to explore key highlights of the release, everyday use cases for Joule agents, and get insights into the roadmap. 

Here are your key resources to help you get started building your own Joule agents:

  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio: Prerequisites, Commercials, and Instructions to begin using Joule Studio 
  • Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions covering Skills and the new Agent Builder features 
  • Create an Agent in Joule Studio: Step-by-step tutorial on how to build and test an agent in Joule Studio
  • Best Practices for Building Agents: Key principles and practices for designing effective Joule Agents 
  • Discovery Center Mission: Get Hands-on experience in creating a Joule Agent with multiple skills and MCP

Hi Joule, where should I get started with the latest learning resources? *

Apart from live enablement sessions, explore our latest on-demand learning resources:

  • To all partners: Test, demo, and develop with Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot by purchasing the Joule Base TDD entitlement (8020592) and any Microsoft 365 environment (you don't necessarily need M365 Copilot to get started). Check out the Microsoft 365 Developer Program to get started.
  • Get hands-on with SAP Document AI! Pre-configured content is automatically delivered as part of the application and can be activated in the schema UI or via the schema APIs. In the video, you will learn how to create your own schemas from scratch in the SAP Document AI workspace. Now it‚Äôs your turn - Go ahead and try it yourself! 

     

* Powered by the machine learning technology of SAP AI Business Services, personalized recommendations are generated for employees, in one place on the Learning home page, based on employee data.

As we look ahead, we‚Äôre excited to share with you a new lineup of learning opportunities designed to help you expand your knowledge and make AI an advantage in your role:

  • February 5: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q4 2025 Option 1 9 am CET - Option 2 4 pm CET
  • February 10, 5 pm CET: Reimagining Business Processes with Joule Agents. Discover how Joule Agents, embedded in core business processes, help organizations transition from insight to action.

Stay tuned for more, and happy learning! üöÄ

Further Resources:

  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This October
  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This November
  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This December

Joule Joule Studio SAP Document AI #Microsoft 365 Copilot SAP Mobile Services

entry.title: üá¶üá∫ Joule Studio: Create Skills and Agents to Extend Joule (Sydney, Australia)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

 

 

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio ‚Äì such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

 

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

 

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 10, 2026 from 012:30 - 16:00 local time in Sydney, Australia(AEDT). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: SAP Sydney Office - Level 13/1 Denison Street, North Sydney

entry.title: Re: How to Use Date Management to Configure Service Contract Dates
entry.content:
Hi @Wei ,
Thank you for your support.

Initial customer requirements
The customer‚Äôs requirement is to set the contract start date as follows:

  • If the date is on or before the 15th of the month, the start date should be set to the 1st of the same month.

  • If it is after the 15th, the start date should be set to the 1st of the following month.

Scope that seems feasible with standard functionality
Add 15 days to the current date, then use RoundTimeExp to round to the beginning of the month.

Examples:

  • 1/10 + 15 days ‚Üí 1/1

  • 1/20 + 15 days ‚Üí 2/1

Sample code

<RoundTimeExp timeunit="MONTH" position="B">

  <MoveTimeExp direction="+">

    <!-- Base date: Today 00:00 -->
    <ConstLocTimeExp date="now" time="000000">
      <VarObjectExp name="SYSTEM"/>
    </ConstLocTimeExp>

    <!-- +15 days -->
    <ConstDuraExp duration="15" timeunit="DAY">
      <VarObjectExp name="SYSTEM"/>
    </ConstDuraExp>

  </MoveTimeExp>

</RoundTimeExp>

Since February has only 28 days, this approach may result in a slight deviation in edge cases. However, as an alternative solution, it seems to work reasonably well.
I am sharing this for potential future use in similar scenarios. Please let me know if you see any concerns or potential risks with this approach.

By the way, when checking this in the Date Rule Editor test context, it sometimes seems that the update does not work correctly, and even with the same logic the calculated date is not always correct.
Is there a recommended or more reliable way to test this logic?

entry.title: Best Practices for Structuring Business Object Migration (Master & Transact. Data) in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

we are preparing the migration of various business objects‚Äîboth master data and transactional data‚Äîinto SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. While the migration itself is executed in the target system, we would like to organize and manage all related activities within SAP Cloud ALM.

I am looking for best practices or recommended approaches on how to structure these migration activities in CALM. In particular:

  • How should migration objects be represented in SAP Cloud ALM?
    Is each migration object typically modeled as a requirement, or user-story, or should migration work be captured primarily through project tasks?

  • How do you structure activities across the target environments (D / Q / P)?
    Would you recommend using sub‚Äëtasks per environment, separate task groups, or another organizational pattern within CALM?

  • Are there common templates or established structuring approaches (e.g., per data domain, per migration wave, per cutover cycle) that have proven useful?

Any recommendations, real-life examples, or references to SAP documentation would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance for your insights!

Best regards,
Tobias Halser

entry.title: Code Connect 2026 is Coming ‚Äì Mark Your Calendars!
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce the return of Code Connect for its third edition, bringing together three dynamic events - UI5con, reCAP, and HANA Tech Con - under one roof. Mark your calendars for July 13 to 16, 2026, and join us in St. Leon-Rot, Germany, or online.

 

What is Code Connect?

Code Connect creates a unique opportunity to experience three specialized events in one location: UI5con, reCAP, and HANA Tech Con, allowing you to dive deep into different aspects of SAP development. Code Connect is designed for developers at every level: Whether you're an SAP veteran or just starting out, this is your chance to connect, learn, and innovate alongside a vibrant community of developers.

 

Your Week at Code Connect

July 13: Code Jam Sessions and Warmup

Kick things off with our Code Jam sessions - a hands-on way to sharpen your skills before the main event. Afterward, join us for a pre-conference networking event to meet fellow attendees in a relaxed setting.

 

 

 

July 14: UI5con

The official program kicks off with UI5con, bringing together UI5 enthusiasts to share insights, explore the latest innovations, and build new connections. Expect expert sessions, interactive workshops, and plenty of opportunities to engage with the UI5 community.

Learn more about UI5con.

 

 
 
 
 

July 15: reCAP

The next day focuses on the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). At reCAP, developers, customers, and partners meet the CAP Product Team to discuss technical concepts, share project experiences, and explore future possibilities.

Learn more about reCAP.

 

 

 

 

 

July 16: HANA Tech Con

The week concludes with HANA Tech Con. Delve into the HANA universe and join development experts, users, and partners to exchange knowledge and ignite new ideas. If you've ever had questions about HANA that you haven't found answers to, this is your chance to get them resolved.

Learn more about HANA Tech Con.

 

Early Bird Process

Planning a longer trip? We offer a limited number of early bird tickets for attendees who need to arrange travel well in advance.

Check our FAQ document for details on how to secure your ticket.

 

Sponsorship Opportunities

Be a part of Code Connect 2026 and become a sponsor to support the developer community at UI5con, reCAP, and HANA Tech Con. By sponsoring Code Connect, you gain access to a diverse audience spanning front-end developers, backend specialists, and database experts ‚Äì all in one event.

Read our sponsorship prospectus to check our sponsorship opportunities.

 

Important Dates

  • Call for Proposals: coming soon
  • Registration Opens: April 10, 2026
  • Agenda Published: Early June 2026
  • Code Connect Week: July 13 to 16, 2026

 

Ready to Connect?

Code Connect 2026 represents more than just learning opportunities. It's about building relationships, sharing knowledge, and being part of a community that's shaping the future of SAP development.

Join us at Code Connect 2026 and be part of a community driving the future of technology. We can't wait to see you there!

entry.title: E-Invoice new features with Release 2511 and 2602 incl. PDF
entry.content:
Since the release 2511 I see a new field in Corporate Accounts under facet Communication >  Collaboration (see screenshot)

The same will be introduced for private accounts with the release 2602.

Why was this introduced, what does it do ?

At first glance, this appears to contradict the concept of an e‚Äëinvoice scenario.

Since we introduced the e‚Äëinvoice functionality, we have received strong customer demand to optionally include the invoice as a PDF in addition to the standard XML-based e‚Äëinvoice. The background is that private individuals can now also request e‚Äëinvoices, and XML/XSLT formats are not user‚Äëfriendly for human readers. Therefore, we agreed to support this option.

The question is: Will this change anything, or is there anything I need to be aware of?

When using the standard e‚Äëinvoice scenario as designed, only the XML file (including its embedded attachments) is sent.

If you enable the option ‚ÄúE‚ÄëInvoice including PDF,‚Äù the email will include the PDF version of the invoice in addition to the XML file. Any attachments will continue to be included as binary content embedded within the XML.

entry.title: Re: Inter-company billing transfer IDOC issue(about enhance)
entry.content:
Standard SAP behavior is when an inter‚Äëcompany billing document is created, an IDoc type like ACC_DOCUMENT INVOIC is generated and forwarded to FI. The account determination (via OBCB, EWLNR key) decides which G/L accounts are hit:

  • EWLNR='*' ‚Üí cost account (e.g., 51110090).
  • EWLNR='99890007' ‚Üí revenue account (e.g., 70100001).

For cost accounts, SAP expects quantity fields (because they are often linked to CO objects). For revenue accounts, the posting schema may not expect quantities, depending on how the account category is configured.

Why the error happens is because, the IDoc segment (e.g., E1EDP01 or ACCIT) carries quantity fields by default. When the line is mapped to a revenue account, the FI posting logic doesn‚Äôt expect a quantity ‚Üí mismatch ‚Üí error. This is aggravated by the fact that screen variant / field status group for revenue accounts suppresses quantity fields.

As already suggested, you can explore EXIT_SAPLIEDI_101 which is a valid and recommended place to implement the clearing of quantity fields for revenue accounts but for information, it is an older enhancement technique (CMOD) and less flexible than BADIs.

Having said that, couple of enhancement options are there where you can manipulate the IDoc before posting

User Exit in IDoc Processing

  • For ACC_DOCUMENT: EXIT_SAPLFACI_001 (function exit for FI IDoc).
  • For INVOIC: EXIT_SAPLVEDF_002 or BADI IDOC_DATA_MAPPER.

You can clear or suppress the quantity field for revenue lines before the IDoc is posted.

BADI / Enhancement

  • BADI_ACC_DOCUMENT ‚Üí allows manipulation of accounting document line items before posting.
  • You can add logic: IF account = revenue account THEN clear quantity fields.

entry.title: Inside the Regulatory Content Service: Everything You Can Access
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve ever wondered why your system doesn‚Äôt show the newest regulatory phrases, lists, or templates right after we announce ‚Äúnew content available,‚Äù you‚Äôre not alone. Those announcements mean new content packages are useable via the Regulatory Content Service‚Äînot that every installed system is automatically updated. To access all the embedded content, you‚Äôll need to be on the latest release of SAP S/4HANA for product compliance. Below, you‚Äôll find a clear mapping of what content is available today and the specific system versions that deliver it, so you can see exactly what you get now‚Äîand what an upgrade unlocks.

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2021 release, the system consumes new and updated regulatory phrases

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 release, the system consumes listed substance content

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 Feature Pack 3 release, the system consumes new and updated regulatory graphics

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2023 Feature Pack 3 release, the system consumes new and updated dangerous goods regulations

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2025 release, the system consumes new and updated product marketability regulations

  • Starting from SAP S/4HANA OP2025 release, the system consumes new and updated safety data sheets regulations

More content is planned to be made accessible in the future. If you have questions, please feel free to leave a comment or message me via LinkedIn.

entry.title: Re: eInvoicing Direct Debit SEPA Mandate #COE#SW01
entry.content:
Latest reply from SAP: 

We have analyzed your incident. The root cause is that when a Billing Document is created using the Billing Document Request Excel upload, the SEPA Mandate Reference is not populated since the standard Excel upload template does not include a field for SEPA Mandate Reference.

It is a known limitation and unfortunately the desired functionality is not available.

At the moment, the solution for Belgium SEPA Direct Debit scenarios would be to use SD-based billing process to ensure full SEPA and e-invoicing compliance. When billing documents are created via Sales Order -> Billing or Contact-> Billing, the SEPA Mandate Reference is correctly derived and passed through to the Belgium e-invoice.

In case there is wish to request a new functionality or product enhancement, SAP has defined a process and tool called Customer Influence (attached SAP Note 2812948), which allows customers to log improvement request themselves and have the ability to work more directly with our product management.

entry.title: How AI in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Is Transforming CRM Adoption, Execution, and Business Value
entry.content:
‚è±This article takes about 10 minutes to read

Introduction

Sales and service organizations are operating under unprecedented pressure. Customers expect fast, relevant, and personalized interactions, while internal teams are tasked with managing increased complexity, more data, and multiple channels - often with the same or fewer resources.

SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 represents a fundamental shift in how CRM supports this reality. It is no longer just a system of record, but a system of intelligence, guidance, and automation, powered by SAP Business AI.

Today, SAP delivers 30+ AI capabilities and use cases connected to Sales and Service Cloud V2, spanning Machine Learning, predictive AI, generative productivity, and agentic automation. This article explains what those capabilities are, how they map to real sales and service processes, and how the next evolution - AI Agents - builds on this foundation without hype or overstatement.

That being said, this blog is intended as a practical SAP Sales and Service V2 AI reference asset for consultants, architects, CIOs, IT leaders, and business stakeholders.

Why AI in CRM Is No Longer Optional

Most CRM challenges today are not caused by a lack of functionality. They stem from missing context and excessive manual effort.

Sales and service teams commonly struggle with:

  • Manually searching through emails, documents, complex Excel spreadsheets, and historical cases
  • Repeating administrative documentation instead of engaging customers
  • Interpreting customer intent across fragmented interactions
  • Scaling personalization across regions and languages
  • Knowing which lead, opportunity, or case deserves attention - now!

AI in Sales & Service Cloud V2 directly addresses these challenges inside the flow of work, reducing friction instead of adding new tools.

One Coherent AI Strategy with Complementary Layers

SAP structures AI for Sales & Service Cloud V2 across three complementary layers ‚Äì where Joule Premium for CX accommodates both premium embedded AI and CX AI toolkit use cases. Together, they enable 30+ AI capabilities, each optimized for a specific class of problems and business outcomes.  See examples below, connected to the main AI focus:

 

Base AI ‚Äî Predictive & Classification Intelligence

Base AI focuses on machine learning‚Äìdriven insights such as prediction, classification, recommendation, and language processing. These capabilities are embedded into Sales and Service Cloud and are available without additional licensing complexity.

Core Base AI Capabilities:

For Sales ScenariosFor Service ScenariosCross-functional Scenarios
  •  Lead & Deal Intelligence (scoring and prioritization)
  • Product Recommendation
  • Business Interaction Intelligence
  • Business Text Intelligence
  • Case Categorization
  • Case Type Determination
  • Similar Case Recommendation
  • Case Topic Analyzer
  • NLP Classification (including sentiment analysis use cases)
  • Profanity Check
  • Machine Translation

 

üí°When Base AI is the right choice - Use Base AI when the problem is repeatable, data-driven, and benefits from historical patterns. It delivers fast ROI with minimal disruption and strong explainability.

 

Embedded Premium AI ‚Äî Generative Productivity Inside CRM

Embedded Premium AI introduces generative intelligence directly into CRM objects in both Sales & Services business objects, transforming structured and unstructured data into concise summaries, insights, and written content.

Core Embedded Premium AI Capabilities

For Sales ScenariosFor Service ScenariosCross-functional Scenarios
    • Account Synopsis
    • Sales Order Summary
    • Survey Trend Summary
    • Lead Booster
    • Email Draft Recommender
  • Case Summary
  • Registered Product Summary
  • Business Information Extraction
  • Email Draft Recommender
  • Utilities Insights
  • Duplicate Check

 

üí°When Embedded Premium AI is the right choice
Use it when speed, productivity, and cognitive load reduction are the primary goals -  especially for frontline sales and service users.

 

CX AI Toolkit ‚Äî Generative, Custom, and Agentic AI

The CX AI Toolkit is where AI becomes configurable, extensible, and increasingly autonomous. It allows organizations to connect AI to enterprise data, define their own use cases, and move beyond assistance toward execution.

Core CX AI Toolkit Capabilities: 

Knowledge & Generative AIAutonomous AI Agents Extensibility
  • Intelligent Q&A
  • Smart Actions
  • Intelligent Customer Profile
  • Autonomous AI Agents 
  • Case Classification Agent
  •  Q&A Agent
  • Quote Creation Agent (Only available for V1 for now, though a similar agent is part of the new & coming set of Agents for V2)
  • Digital Service Agent
  • Knowledge Creation Agent
  • AI Tools (sales & service content tools as one capability area)
  • Custom Tool Builder
  • Custom Agent Builder

 

üí°When the Toolkit is the right choice
Use it when AI must span multiple steps, integrate enterprise knowledge, or act autonomously rather than simply recommend.

 

Business Process - AI Across the Sales and Service v2 Lifecycle

Across lead management, opportunity execution, visits, and order handling, SAP provides a broad set of AI capabilities tightly aligned to sales processes.

Example of Sales Process powered by SAP Business AI:

Key outcomes include:

  • Predictive prioritization of leads and opportunities
  • Faster and better-informed account preparation
  • AI-generated discovery questions and follow-up emails
  • Survey-driven insights for visit planning
  • Automated quote handling through AI Agents

That said, and as illustrated in the picture above, Sales Cloud V2 evolves from a tracking system into a decision-support and execution assistant.

Regarding Service Cloud V2 applies AI across intake, understanding, resolution, and knowledge creation, reducing both handling time and customer effort.

Example of Service Process powered by SAP Business AI

Key outcomes include:

  • Automated categorization and routing of incoming cases
  • Instant understanding through summaries of long interaction histories
  • Faster resolution using similar-case intelligence
  • Entity extraction from unstructured emails and documents
  • Continuous growth of the knowledge base through AI Agents

That said, and as illustrated in the picture above, Service Cloud v2 moves from reactive ticket handling to proactive resolution orchestration.

Intelligent Q&A: The Foundation of Trustworthy AI

Intelligent Q&A, powered by RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), is one of the core building blocks behind the 30+ AI use cases in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2. In simple terms, it allows people ‚Äî and AI Agents ‚Äî to ask questions in plain language and get answers backed by real CRM data and enterprise documents, with source references for transparency. 

Sometimes customers notice that answers vary in quality. That‚Äôs usually because of how RAG works under the hood: the system looks for the most relevant pieces of information across indexed files, emails, tickets, and product data, and then asks the LLM to generate a grounded answer. The model is probabilistic, so answers can change slightly from one attempt to the next, even when grounded in the same data.

See details about the flow in the image below:

In practice, results get better when the indexed content is well structured (e.g., clean text-based documents). With that in mind, questions that ask for guidance or clarification (e.g., ‚Äúhow to‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat is the policy‚Ä¶‚Äù) tend to produce the most accurate answers.
Examples include resolving an issue, understanding a process, or checking a product policy. On the other hand, requests that ask for summaries, counts, or cross-object overviews don‚Äôt perform as well, such as asking for opportunity summaries or ticket totals.

At a higher level, Intelligent Q&A gives organizations something essential: AI that can be explained, audited, and trusted by CIOs, architects, and compliance teams ‚Äî which is why it‚Äôs such a critical foundation for enterprise AI.

From Assistance to Autonomy: The New Role of CX AI Agents

SAP‚Äôs CX AI Agents are moving customer experience from ‚ÄúAI that assists humans‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI that performs routine work autonomously‚Äù ‚Äî all while staying connected to SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 data, business logic, and governance.

Instead of generic chatbots, these agents are designed to perform specific enterprise tasks such as classifying tickets, creating knowledge articles, answering product questions, or compiling case information. They combine:

‚úî Continuous context awareness (tickets, emails, catalog, meeting transcripts)
‚úî Task execution using CX AI Toolkit tools and CRM APIs
‚úî Business guardrails (policies, confidence scores, approvals)

Depending on the use case, agents can either assist or fully automate workflows.

Examples of Autonomous & Semi-Autonomous CX Agents

  • Case Classification Agent ‚Üí categorizes incoming cases based on business rules
  • Knowledge Creation Agent ‚Üí generates KBAs from new tickets
  • Digital Service Agent ‚Üí responds to common inquiries in natural language
  • Q&A Agent ‚Üí answers operational questions using CRM, ticket, or product data
  • Custom AI Agents ‚Üí automate organization-specific tasks using custom prompts and tools

This model doesn‚Äôt eliminate humans ‚Äî it shifts them toward value work, while AI handles:

  • First-level inquiries
  • Case enrichment & categorization
  • Article creation
  • Data retrieval & validation
  • Repetitive information lookups

Human-in-the-Loop by Design

When confidence is low or approvals are required, the agent automatically escalates. This ensures:

  • Control over sensitive actions
  • Transparency on data sources
  • Trust for compliance & audit teams

The long-term outcome is not human replacement, but:

  • Fewer manual clicks
  • Faster resolutions
  • Better customer responses
  • Higher productivity for sales & service teams

As organizations add custom prompts and tools, CX AI Agents become an orchestration layer between enterprise data, SAP applications, and human expertise, supporting a realistic pathway toward automation in Sales & Service Cloud V2.

Adoption Guidance ‚Äì Matching Business Needs to the Right AI Use Case

 

Examples of lenses and guidance to consider‚Äã:

Or rather, a simple and defensible adoption lens could be :

  • Base AI ‚Üí Prediction, scoring, and classification
  • Embedded Premium AI ‚Üí Summaries, narratives, productivity acceleration
  • CX AI Toolkit & Agents ‚Üí Automation, autonomy, and customization

The objective is not ‚Äúmore AI‚Äù, but clear value, no overlap, and controlled total cost of ownership.

Furthermore, there are several assets available that can support you, provide adoption guidance, and inform your decision-making. Please see below:

  • Joule Premium Adoption Playbook for SAP Sales and Service Cloud (More CX AI toolkit capabilities focused)
  • Mastering the AI Mindset - Co-Creating the Future of AI & Customer Experience with SAP CX
  • The Art of Possible: Why Now Is the Time for SAP Sales and Service AI Agents in Customer Experience
  • AI Value Calculator - Calculate your potential savings
  • PUMP Package ‚Äì SAP Joule Premium for Customer Experience
  • SAP Business AI estimator

Agentic AI - What‚Äôs Coming Next

Agentic AI in SAP Sales Cloud v2: Join the Customer Engagement Initiative

See more HERE.

And also, roadmap explorer HERE.

Final Takeaway: AI as a CRM Operating Model

SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 now delivers:

  • 30+ AI capabilities available today
  • A clear progression from insight ‚Üí productivity ‚Üí autonomy
  • A trusted AI foundation aligned with enterprise governance

For consultants, architects, CIOs, and business leaders, this is no longer an innovation discussion. It is an operating model decision that defines how customer-facing teams work at scale. Organizations that adopt AI intentionally will not just work faster ‚Äî they will work smarter, with less friction and more impact.

Thank you for reading, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you need any support.

entry.title: SAP Data Services, generated ABAP DF program can not be transported with variables!!
entry.content:
hello experts,

I try to generate an ABAP program related to an ABAP Dataflow, the DF uses a global variable (or a parameter) => Upload Ok.

I try to release the CR in SAP S/4HANA 2021 system => CR releasae Ok.

When I transport there are errors related to how the Global variables or parameters in ABAP dataflow are translated in PARAMETER $PARAM# in ABAP program (# = 1,2,3... positional parameter identifier).

So during STMS transport of a generated ABAP program from an ABAP dataflow, a check on ABAP consistency is made (parameters needs to start with literals or '_').
By default the code generated by SAP DS contains the '$' symbol as first character.

This prevent of transporting any ABAP dataflow that is using Gobal variables or Parameters.

There is no workaround or mention in SAP Help (tested an export of PDF and query to notebooklm),

I can't find any workaround in SAP notes.

 

This limitation prevent the usage of "Execute Preloaded" with SAP S/4 or SAP ECC production datastore, as the ABAP programs can not be transported beccause of '$' issue, and with closed client we can not directly or manually upload these programs to S/4HANA productive tenant.

So the only workaround I found is open the client to changes and use "Generate and Execute" with a productive S/4HANA system.

 

Do you have any workaround?

best regards,

Alberto

entry.title: Re: Complete Guide: Setting Up CAP Plugin for Advanced Event Mesh with OAuth Authentication
entry.content:
Hello @Fiona_Zhang_FZ 
Not out of the box, no.

The advanced-event-mesh plugin looks for service-instances and they must be available in the same org/space the application is running in.

The only chance you have is to "patch" the advanced-event-mesh plugin and make it work via User-Provided Services:

const _getCredsFromVcap = test => {
  const vcap = process.env.VCAP_SERVICES && JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES)
  if (!vcap) throw new Error('No VCAP_SERVICES in process environment')
  // Node-Patch -> allow to iterate user-provded services
  for (const binding in vcap) {
    for (const instance of vcap[binding]) {
      if (test(instance)) return instance.credentials
    }
  }
  /*
  for (const name in vcap) {
    const srv = vcap[name][0]
    if (test(srv)) return srv.credentials
  }
  */
}

And:

const _validateBroker = async (mgmt_uri, subaccountId) => {
  // via VCAP_SERVICES to avoid specifying _another_ cds.requires service
  // * Node-Patch -> allow for user-provided services with a specific tag
  const creds = _getCredsFromVcap(srv => (srv.plan === 'aem-validation-service-plan' || srv.tags?.includes('aem-validation-service')))
// ...
}

Doing so, you could:
- Create mandatory service-instances in the Global Account where AEM is provisioned
- Copy them over to the other Global Account as User-Provided Services

But his is kinda hacky and requires you to change the original coding of the CAP Plugin (meaning, you need to take care about upgrades, changes, fixes, etc...).


Best,
R.

to
